title: How to Season Spaghetti

steps.headline: Add red pepper flakes or black pepper to add spiciness.
steps.description: Sprinkle 2 grams (0.071 oz) of black pepper or red pepper flakes on top of your spaghetti to add a spicy flavor. Taste the pasta before adding any more pepper to make sure it isn’t too hot. Pepper can also be added to sauces to make them spicier. Don’t add too much red pepper flakes or black pepper or it will completely overwhelm the taste of the spaghetti.

steps.headline: Sprinkle grated cheese on the spaghetti to add a salty, cheesy flavor.
steps.description: Traditionally, spaghetti is topped with parmesan, mozzarella, ricotta, or romano cheese. Add 2 grams (0.071 oz) of cheese to your bowl of spaghetti, or 60–80 grams (2.1–2.8 oz) to a sauce or pot of spaghetti. Mix in the cheese and taste it before adding more. You can put more than 1 kind of cheese on your spaghetti to add more flavor. The distinct taste of each cheese will alter the flavor of the dish. Parmesan and romano cheese are sharp and salty. Mozzarella cheese is less salty than parmesan but is better for melting. Ricotta has a mild flavor but uniquely soft texture.

steps.headline: Add basil for a sweet aromatic flavor.
steps.description: Basil is an herb that is popularly added to spaghetti to impart a nutty, peppery, and herbaceous flavor. Add 2–4 grams (0.071–0.141 oz) of freshly minced basil or dried basil to the top of your spaghetti or in your spaghetti sauce. Taste a fresh basil leaf before adding it to your pasta to make sure that you like the flavor. Basil is one of the base ingredients for pesto sauce.

steps.headline: Sprinkle parsley into the sauce to add some color.
steps.description: Add 2–4 grams (0.071–0.141 oz) of fresh or dried parsley to your spaghetti to add some green flecks to your sauce. This will lighten up the look of your dish and will add an herbaceous and fresh taste. Parsley is an ingredient in a variety of different pasta sauces.

steps.headline: Mix garlic into the spaghetti to give it a nutty flavor.
steps.description: Mince up 1-3 cloves of garlic and heat them in a pan with olive oil before adding it to the pasta. If you don’t have fresh garlic, you can add 2–4 grams (0.071–0.141 oz) of garlic powder to the pasta instead. Remember to mix the pasta thoroughly so that the garlic is well incorporated. Adding raw, fresh garlic to the pasta may be overpowering and very peppery tasting.

steps.headline: Mix brown butter into the spaghetti for a rich and decadent taste.
steps.description: Melt 1 stick of butter in a saucepan on medium heat. Mix the melted butter in the pan until it turns a golden brown. This sauce will give the spaghetti a rich and nutty flavor.

steps.headline: Mix salt into the spaghetti to enhance all the other spices and flavors.
steps.description: Salt will help bring out and elevate the other flavors and prevent your spaghetti from tasting bland. Sprinkle 1–2 grams (0.035–0.071 oz) of salt on top of the pasta and mix it in. Salt is one of the most important things to season with.

steps.headline: Make marinara for a popular tomato-based sauce.
steps.description: To make homemade marinara sauce, saute garlic and onions in olive oil for 2-3 minutes. Then, add a can of crushed or whole tomatoes to the pan and mix it together with a spoon. Cook the sauce on medium-low heat for 15-30 minutes. Add thyme, basil, and oregano to enhance the flavor of your marinara sauce. Traditionally, you can top this dish with parmesan cheese. If you don’t want to make your own sauce, you can buy a jar of marinara sauce from the grocery store.

steps.headline: Season the spaghetti with olive oil and garlic for a simple solution.
steps.description: Heat ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of olive oil in a large saucepan. Just before the oil reaches the smoking point, add 4 cloves of minced garlic to the oil and stir it with the spoon. Cook the garlic for 30 seconds to 1 minute and turn off the stove. Toss your spaghetti in the olive oil, for a quick and simple solution. Add dry or fresh basil, parsley, and oregano to add more flavor to the sauce. Parmesan and romano cheese go great with this dish. Sprinkle some red pepper flakes into the sauce to add some heat. Do not cook the garlic for too long or it will burn. If you don’t have fresh garlic, then you can substitute it with powdered garlic.

steps.headline: Add ground beef or turkey to marinara to create a ragu.
steps.description: Brown ground beef or ground turkey in a saucepan with onions and garlic. Once the meat is cooked through, add crushed or whole tomatoes into the pan and cook it on medium-low heat for 15-30 minutes. Add spices like salt, pepper, and basil to the pasta sauce to add more flavor. Consuming raw or undercooked meat can lead to food poisoning.

steps.headline: Create a pesto for a vegetarian option.
steps.description: Make pesto by blending 50 grams (1.8 oz) of pine nuts, 150 grams (5.3 oz) of basil, 80 ml (2.7  fl oz) of olive oil, and 50 grams (1.8 oz) of parmesan cheese together in a blender. Then, pour the pesto on top of your spaghetti and mix it in thoroughly before serving it. Taste the sauce to make sure it tastes good and add more ingredients to alter the flavor.

steps.headline: Top the spaghetti with alfredo sauce for a cheesy option.
steps.description: Heat 250 millilitres (8.5  fl oz) of heavy cream, 150 grams (5.3 oz) of parmesan cheese, and 1 stick of unsalted butter in a pot or pan. Turn the heat to medium and mix the sauce until all of the cheese and butter melts. Add salt and pepper to taste before mixing it in with your spaghetti. Do not turn the stove on too high or the cheese and cream will separate. If the parmesan cheese rises to the top and floats on the surface of the cream, it means your sauce has separated. If your sauce separates, you can emulsify the sauce by stirring it vigorously or by gradually adding small amounts of cornstarch or flour until the sauce tightens up. Alternatively, you could make an easy, extra-rich alfredo sauce with cream cheese if you have difficulty with traditional alfredo sauce.

steps.headline: Create a carbonara sauce.
steps.description: Slice guanciale, pancetta, or bacon into ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) squares and heat them in a skillet until you render down the fat, then turn off the heat. In a separate bowl, mix 2 eggs and 100 g (3.5 oz) of grated pecorino romano cheese. Then, pour the egg and cheese mixture into the pan with the meat and stir it together until the sauce thickens. Pour the sauce over the spaghetti and mix it well. If your pan is too hot, the eggs will scramble. If they start to harden too much, add water to the sauce. Guanciale is the most traditional and best option to use when making a carbonara sauce.
